title: Gender Discrimination in the Workplace
headline: Investigate the origins and causes of gender-based bias and the actions taken to combat it in this free online course.
description: This free online gender discrimination course details the key issues and concepts surrounding gender equality and discrimination in the workplace, through a careful study of societal structures and gender ideologies. This course examines topics including legislation on human rights, collective bargaining in workplaces, cultural roles, wage compression and the gender pay gap, highlighting how conscious and unconscious bias can impact us all.
courseDescription:
The course begins with an introduction to gender discrimination in the workplace and an examination of the gender pay gap, dissecting global statistics, and drawing insights from them. This course further discusses labour force participation, where it points out the bias in job availability based on gender stereotyping, as well as the comparative educational disadvantages that women experience in certain societies. Have you ever wondered why women are still far less likely to be in a position of leadership than men? This course analyzes recent statistics in a bid to find out why. In the first module, the course touches on gender ideologies and social role theory, giving an overview of the topics and pointing out the role of social interactions as a major player in gender discrimination. It further clarifies the misconceptions of ‘sex’ and ‘gender’, and the basic concepts of ‘collective bargaining’ and ‘market forces’ are discussed. With regard to collective bargaining, some of the conditions to consider for paid parental leave, as well as its importance, are highlighted. In the first module, you will also learn about the factors associated with gender equality in any society, which includes national and international legislation, and cultural roles for women.

In module two, you will learn more about the topic of legislation by reviewing the legislative constructs of a representative sample of countries and assessing the impact of these systems, specifically in the context of the cultures in which they are applied. You will look into the legislative systems of nations like the United States, India, China, Brazil and Russia, and how their separate laws approach the issue of gender discrimination in the workplace. The legislative articles of the European Union on gender equality and pregnancy in the workplace are also explained. You will learn about ‘global cultures’, the concept of a ‘cultural identity’ and how these affect gender discrimination. Finally, in the third module, you will learn about parental leave and collective bargaining in-depth, and discover the International Labour Organization’s (ILO) guidelines for such bargaining. Additional topics include wage regulation, wage compression, minimum wage laws and the supply of female labour.

Virtually all industrialized nations have passed equal pay and equal opportunity legislation but research has shown that women earn less than men and that women are less likely to be in positions of leadership than men. Legislative systems have been designed to enforce gender equality in the workplace so why does the gender pay gap still exist? Although there are accompanying international laws opposing gender discrimination, statistics suggest that gender discrimination is still pervasive in the world today. Worldwide indices point to a gender wage gap of at least 13% to 15% according to a 2020 report, which puts a question mark over the effectiveness of the relevant legislative systems. A lot of the problems that arise can be attributed to a lack of awareness of this issue, particularly for national governments and employers. There is a growing need for businesses and employers to adopt and enforce a gender-equal approach to their organizational processes in order to help foster gender equality and support their governments in the fight against the subjugation of women. This free online course provides an excellent grounding in the topic of workplace gender discrimination. Enrol now and you can begin studying today.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes

  • At the end of this module, the student will be able to:
    • Define employment discrimination.
    • Discuss statistics relating to women in leadership positions.
    • Recount a brief history of gender issues in the workplace.
    • Explain Social Role Theory.
    • Identify the factors most highly associated with gender and employment equality.  

  • Overview

  • In this module, we investigate gender discrimination in the context of employment, which is defined as a bias based on biological gender and/or gender identity that results in workplace inequality. It can be direct or indirect and should be measured based on its effects, both tangible and intangible. Direct sex discrimination occurs when a person is treated less favorably because of his or her sex; indirect discrimination occurs when an imbalance results from an application of a seemingly neutral criterion by a decision-maker that results in a disadvantage to one gender and an advantage to the other.

    Employment discrimination is any form of unequal treatment in the hiring, assignment of duties, pay, promotions, layoffs, management, or supervision of individuals based on any factors other than job qualifications or performance.

  • Gender Ideologies

  • All societies have gender ideologies, just as they have belief systems about other significant areas of life, such as health and disease, the natural world, and social relationships, including family. But cultures, over time, have erected complex and elaborate edifices around them, creating systems of meaning that often barely resemble what is natural and innate1. One powerful aspect of culture, and a reason cultural norms feel so natural, is that we learn culture the way we learn our native language: without formal instruction, in social contexts, picking it up from others around us, without thinking. Soon, it becomes deeply embedded in our brains2. One’s biological sex is a different phenomenon than one’s gender, which is socially and historically constructed3. Gender is a set of culturally invented expectations and therefore constitutes a role one assumes, learns, and performs, more or less consciously. It is an “identity” one can in theory choose, although there is tremendous pressure in some societies to conform to the gender role and identity linked to your biological sex.
  • 1. Mukhopadhyay, C., and Blumenfield, T. (2017). Gender and Sexuality. In N. Brown, L.Tubelle de González, & T. McIlwraith (Eds.), Perspectives: An Open Invitation to Cultural Anthropology (pp. 231-285). http://perspectives.americananthro.org/.

    2. ibid.

    3. See, for example, Judith Butler, Gender Trouble: Feminism and the Subversion of Identity (New York: Routledge, 1999 [1990]).

  • Factors Affecting Gender Equality in the Workplace

  • Several factors are correlated with gender equality in employment: 
    1. The presence of strong and enforceable national legislation mandating equal treatment.
    2. Cultural developments influencing the role of women in society.
    3. The strength of collective bargaining conventions, and parental leave/childcare options.
    4. Minimum wage laws, wage compression, and the female labor supply. We will consider these in detail in the next several sections.

  • UN Discrimination Against Women Convention

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The United Nations addressed gender discrimination in its Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW), adopted in 1979 by the UN General Assembly. 

    It is a statement of human rights and fundamental freedom for women and makes recommendations on steps nations can take to end discrimination. CEDAW defines gender discrimination as "...any distinction, exclusion or restriction made on the basis of sex which has the effect or purpose of impairing or nullifying the recognition, enjoyment or exercise by women, irrespective of their marital status, on a basis of equality of men and women, of human rights and fundamental freedoms in the political, economic, social, cultural, civil or any other field."1 
  • 1. https://www.un.org/womenwatch/daw/cedaw/cedaw.htm

  • Lesson Summary

    • Gender discrimination in the context of employment is a bias based on biological gender or gender identification that results in workplace inequality. 
    • It may be the result of actions by a person in a position of authority that are taken consciously, or that are taken unknowingly because of deeply embedded biases that a person may have that would be contrary to their more reasoned judgment.
    • Factors that are correlated with a more gender-neutral work environment include the presence of enabling legislation establishing gender neutrality as a legal principle, a supportive cultural environment, collective bargaining conventions, parental leave and childcare options, and other political and economic factors.

  • Learning Outcomes

  •  After learning this module, the student will be able to: 
    • Identify the types of approaches to gender relations that appear in national constitutions and laws.
    • Assess the impact of each of these types of approaches.
    • Describe the impact of culture on interpretations of legislative initiatives.

  • Legislative Systems in Comparative Countries

  • In this Module, we will review the legislative constructs of a representative sample of countries and assess the impact of these systems, especially in the context of the cultures in which they are applied. We will begin with a review of the constitutional provisions and key pieces of legislation in each of the selected countries.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • The USA and the United Kingdom
    Neither the Constitution of the United States nor that of the United Kingdom directly address women’s equality under the law. In the USA, the 14th Amendment of the Constitution, enacted in 1868, guarantees that all citizens should enjoy equal protection under the laws of the federal government and in each of the states. It was intended to protect male citizens regardless of whether a person had been enslaved before the USA Civil War (1861 – 1865) and was not interpreted as applying to women for nearly a century after its passage. In 1976, the US Supreme Court ruled that under the 14th amendment men and women could be treated differently under the law only if it served an “important governmental objective,” a term that has remained somewhat vague as it has only been defined by case law.

  • Russia
    Russia’s Constitution (1993, Art. 19) guarantees equal rights to men and women, and under the Labor Code (51 – ST 255), women have the right to paid maternity leave, paid parental leave, and unpaid parental leave that can be extended until the child is three. Russia has enacted laws that prohibit women from taking on work that might interfere with their “reproductive health” and general well-being. Jobs that are barred are, for example, ones that would entail their lifting more than nine kg. (20 lbs.) twice an hour, along with occupations such as miner or diver, working in a chemical or metallurgical factory or driving long-distance trucks.
  • Japan
    In past decades, Japan’s economy has been hampered by a combination of growing demographic challenges, including a low birth rate, strict immigration policies, and a shrinking and rapidly aging population. To bolster the workforce and spur the economy, in 2013, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a new policy to promote women’s career development. In 2015, the Japanese Diet passed the “Law Concerning the Promotion of Women’s Career Activities” (Law No. 64, 4-Sep-15), which is intended to enable “women to fully demonstrate their personalities and capabilities, based on the actual conditions of gender disparities” (Art. 2.1). The Act further acknowledges that “women who participate in working lives are compelled to leave work due to marriage, pregnancy, giving birth, child-rearing, caring for other people and other reasons relating to home lives” (Art. 2.2). The Act acknowledges that workforce participation may be affected by a person’s biology, but also accepts that Social Role Theory is embraced by a significant portion of the Japanese society and provides a path for its accommodation in the workforce. While the Act uses the term “gender equality,” its intent is perhaps better characterized as “gender equity” – a term that suggests fairness rather than an exact parity as its central goal.

Jobs that are barred are, for example, ones that would entail their lifting more than nine kg. (20 lbs.) twice an hour, along with occupations such as miner or diver, working in a chemical or metallurgical factory or driving long-distance trucks.
  • Japan
    In past decades, Japan’s economy has been hampered by a combination of growing demographic challenges, including a low birth rate, strict immigration policies, and a shrinking and rapidly aging population. To bolster the workforce and spur the economy, in 2013, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced a new policy to promote women’s career development. In 2015, the Japanese Diet passed the “Law Concerning the Promotion of Women’s Career Activities” (Law No. 64, 4-Sep-15), which is intended to enable “women to fully demonstrate their personalities and capabilities, based on the actual conditions of gender disparities” (Art. 2.1). The Act further acknowledges that “women who participate in working lives are compelled to leave work due to marriage, pregnancy, giving birth, child-rearing, caring for other people and other reasons relating to home lives” (Art. 2.2). The Act acknowledges that workforce participation may be affected by a person’s biology, but also accepts that Social Role Theory is embraced by a significant portion of the Japanese society and provides a path for its accommodation in the workforce. While the Act uses the term “gender equality,” its intent is perhaps better characterized as “gender equity” – a term that suggests fairness rather than an exact parity as its central goal.

  • A Definition of Culture

  • Culture is an umbrella term that encompasses the many social behaviors and norms found in societies. It is something that is rooted in common histories but is also a living and vibrant thing full of tensions and contradictions as societies modernize and urbanize.

    Groups have identities based on the common experiences of what they believe to be their history – something that can be based in fact or can be edited as needed, consciously or unconsciously, to serve the current situation. These experiences give group members a set of tools to use in solving problems, facing challenges, and – most importantly – in encountering new ideas. It gives people a way of filtering or classifying newly encountered things. A person’s attachment to a culture can be either strong or weak, and fixed or pliable.

    Two of the strongest determinants of cultural identity are religion and national or ethnic origin. National governments tend to promote the development of a unique culture within their territorial boundaries to inspire unity and common purpose; religious institutions develop and promulgate moral and ethical codes. While these two aspects of culture are important, they are not exclusive and not always the most important to any given individual. For example, in large cities with diverse populations, cultural identity is based primarily on locational contiguity.

  • Module 2 - Lesson Summary

    • Virtually all industrialized nations have passed equal pay and equal opportunity legislation addressing gender.
    • In many countries, the concept of equal rights is embedded in their constitutions and made a basis for further enabling legislation. 
    • Despite this, there is no country in which women feel that their rights are equal to those of men.
    • While legislation ensuring the equality of genders may be helpful to those people who see this as a societal goal, it is not sufficient on its own to achieve this end. For that to occur, there must be a supportive culture.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After studying this module, the students will be able to:
    • Show the effect of collective bargaining on gender equality.
    • Demonstrate how parental leave impacts the workplace and its employees.
    • Assess the impact of minimum wage laws and wage compression on gender pay equality.
    • Explain how shortages and surpluses in the supply of female labor affect gender pay equality.

  • Types of Parental Leave

  • Leave in connection with childbirth or adoption is not generally well defined by international convention, and so there is much variation in how it is interpreted by individual countries. The International Labour Organization offers guidance on this topic in its Maternity Protection Convention (C-183), which provides guidelines for maternity benefits and for restrictions on the types of work that may be prejudicial to the health of a pregnant woman or her expected child. While an impressive list of countries has ratified this convention, it has yet to be adopted by a plurality of the world’s leading economic powers.

    • Paternity Leave

  • Minimum Wage Laws

  • In moderately to highly developed economies, enacting minimum wage laws or raising minimum wage levels has the impact of advancing gender wage equality. Raising the pay of those who have minimum wage jobs will tend to narrow the gap between the lowest pay and the average pay that workers earn.

  • Select an Image from the Gallery

  • Because women have a disproportionately high share of minimum wage jobs worldwide, this action tends to narrow the wage gap between genders, but this simple mathematical relationship works only in those countries whose economies are developed and where the most common form of income is from paid labor. In relatively undeveloped economies, the lowest tier of income is most commonly from self-employment, and in these cases, raising the minimum wage will not produce effective results.1, 2

  • Wage Compression

  • Wage compression also works to narrow the wage gap between genders, again, without addressing any of the root causes of gender inequality but in a different way. Wage compression occurs when employees with the same skills and job functions are paid differently.

    Wage compression may happen when:
    • Employee wage increases have not kept pace with inflation. Over time, new employees can begin to earn salaries very close to, equal to, or greater than those of the more experienced employees.
    • Market demand for a particular skill set increases quickly. The price of new entrants to the market more quickly than for those who retain their jobs and wait for annual pay increases. This is particularly true for newly formed companies with a need for employees with a specific skill set.
  • In these cases, the normal pay gap between experienced workers and new hires erodes, opening aggressively competitive wage opportunities for newer and less experienced workers.

  • Lesson Summary

    • Several labor market factors work to forward the goal of gender equality, albeit by addressing some of its symptoms rather than its underlying causes.
    • Collective bargaining is a system by which females may effectively lobby for fair pay, better working conditions, and improved benefits. When collective bargaining authorities are supported by legislation that establishes parental leave and non-toxic, non-hazardous working conditions, they have a firm basis on which to support their female as well as male members. 
    • Further, collective bargaining agents may seek to establish working conditions more favorable than the minimum standards that are set by law. On the other hand, aggressive action in support of improved working conditions have, on occasion, given organizations reason to assess the overall cost of hiring female, as opposed to male, employees – and may dampen the rate at which they are hired as well as the level of compensation they are offered.
    • While there are many varieties of parental leave, the most commonly found forms are maternity/pregnancy leave, paternity leave, parental leave, and home care leave. Except for the USA, almost all OECD countries meet the ILO standard for paid maternity leave of 14 weeks, and most countries provide benefits that replace somewhere between one-third and two-thirds of previous earnings, but this varies considerably across countries. 
    • Paid leave for childbirth is particularly important for low-income families, as it increases the likelihood that mothers will return to employment after the leave benefits expire.

  • Learning Outcomes

  • After completing this module, you will be able to:
    • Integrate your assessment of the legislative, cultural, workplace, and labor market forces on gender equality in the workplace.
    • Make an overall assessment of the current state and likely path of gender equality in the workplace.

  • Legislation

  • Gender equality was termed a human right by the United Nations in its Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW 1979). It is a statement of human rights and fundamental freedoms for women and makes recommendations on steps nations can take to end gender-based discrimination. 

    In many countries, the concept of equal rights of citizens without regard to gender (and other distinctions including race, religion, etc.) is embraced in national constitutions. In every industrialized country, the concept of gender equality is supported by legislation.

  • Culture

  • Culture is an umbrella term that encompasses the many social behaviors and norms found in societies. It is something that is rooted in common histories but is also a living and vibrant thing full of tensions and contradictions as societies modernize and urbanize. 

    Cultural traditions, supported by governments, social organizations, workplaces, and families, often preserve patterns of established behavior. Counter to this, segments of society, for example, the women’s liberation movement, may develop first as a splinter group but as the viewpoints, they express gain popularity, they become integrated into the mainstream and take a place as part of the core culture.

  • Labour Market Factors

  • Five labour market factors: the strength of collective bargaining conventions, the availability of parental leave, minimum wage laws, wage compression, and the supply and demand for female labour, each impact the metrics typically used to assess gender equality in the workplace. 

    The first, collective bargaining conventions facilitate the availability of parental leave and help to ensure the implementation of minimum wage laws along with other legal and regulatory mandates. The last two are market adjustments that work to repair structural imbalances in wages and benefits that occur through market forces that have been tainted by a filter of gender bias.
